text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN

Former Wallaby winger Barry Lea has been sent home from the Queensland rugby union tour of South Africa, after signing with the Canberra Raiders rugby league club. Lea's decision to switch football codes was financial - signing one year contract worth $A50,000. However, the Queensland Reds are already planning to buy Lea back for the 1998 season. Page 18.

Cronulla rugby league team has maintained its unbeaten Super League record with a 13-12 win last night over Canterbury at Belmore Oval. A 70th minute field goal by five-eighth Mitch Healey gave the Sharks a one point lead after having been deadlocked at 2-all for much of the second half. Page 18.

Sydney horse trainer Alan Bell last night ruled Millward unlikely to start in the $A2 million Tooheys Golden Slipper Stakes. He described himself as a "conscientious objector" to paying the $A100,000 late fee which would be incurred as Millward was not oiginally nominated to run in the Slipper. Page 18.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Australian pole vaulting sensation Emma George has won silver at the Paris world indoor championships. George was favourite to take out the first major international competition to feature women's pole vaulting, however she said it was first stop on her ourney for Olympic glory. Page 41.

Eight Australians playing basketball in the United States have made it into the NCAA national tournament championships. The college basketball play-offs are contested by the best 64 men's and women's teams in the country. The play-offs begin at the weekend. Page 41.

Australian rugby union star David Campese has shown interest at competing in Kuala Lumpur next year when rugby sevens will be included in the Commonwealth Games. Although Campese has retired from international football, he is still willing and able to be involved in ay big sevens tournament. Page 41.
THE AGE

Professional Australian sportspeople have been warned they will not be paid when they compete in next year's Kuala Lumpur Games. Commonwealth Games chief Arthur Tunstall issued the warning yesterday saying it was strict Games policy that no money would be paid to athletes. English cricketers were at one stage threatened to boycott the Games, agitating for appearance money. Page B8.

Australia's top netball official has labelled men as netball "jokes" and said they have no place in major competitions such as the Commonwealth Games. In response to the exclusion of men's netball from the Kulua Lumpur Games, Netball Australia's executive director Pam Smith said men will be included when they can play at a level which is acceptable. Page B8.

Essendon Australian Rules footballer James Hird will miss valuable match practice in the lead up to the 1997 season after straining a medial ligament in his ankle last week. The Brownlow medallist rolled his ankle at training on Friday night, but officias are confident he will be ready for the team's first-round clash with Carlton. Page B6.
THE HERALD SUN

Australian racehorse Octagonal passed the A$5 million mark with a win in yesterday's A$1.25 million Australian Cup. Octagonal farewelled Flemington racecourse in front of a crowd of more than 21,000. His next, and probably last challenge, will be the Mecedes Classic in Sydney. Page 85.

Australian golfer Steve Elkington won the Doral Open in Miami yesterday with a two-stroke victory. Elkington started the final round two strokes behind the lead, but hit the front with an eagle at the tough par-4 third hole. He finished at 13-under 275 and collected his seventh victory on the US Tour. Page 81.

Australian tennis sensation Mark Philippoussis' sights are set on breaking into the world's top 10, after winning his second singles title in Scottsdale yesterday. Philippoussis, 20, beat eighth-seeded American Richey Reneberg in straight sets to take out the Arizona Tennis Classic. His win is set to take his world ranking from 42nd to the low 30s when new rankings are issued. Page 81.
THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

Friday night's return of the Australian Rugby League was beaten in the ratings by the broadcast of the 1997 Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras. The Mardi Gras attracted 516,000 viewers, 158,000 more than the ARL's best of 358,000. An ARL spokesman said in spiteof the loss, they were happy with the ratings. Page 61.

Australian Rugby League and Super League officials yesterday admitted they have given away thousands of tickets to boost attendance figures at opening round matches. Officials from both sides have defended the move, denying claims it was an underhanded wy of gathering support, instead describing it as a show of goodwill after the ARL-Super League split. Page 61.

Thieves have stolen around $A10,000 worth of equipment from Olympic kayaker Brian Morton on the eve of his Australian selection trials. The theft is a major setback for Morton, who finished fourth in the K4 1000 metres event at the 1995 world championshis. Page 57.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
